The concept of love, however, is subject to debate. Some deny the existence of love, calling it a recently invented abstraction. Moreover, approximately 13 percent of cultures reportedly have no word for love.<ref>{{cite book | author=Ackerman, Diane | title=A Natural History of Love | publisher=Vintage Books | year=1994 | id=ISBN 0679761837}}</ref> Others maintain that love exists but is undefinable; being a quantity which is [[spirituality|spiritual]], [[metaphysical]], or [[philosophical]] in nature. Love is one of the most common themes in art.
 
The concept of love, however, is subject to debate. Some deny the existence of love, calling it a recently invented abstraction. Moreover, approximately 13 percent of cultures reportedly have no word for love.<ref>{{cite book | author=Ackerman, Diane | title=A Natural History of Love | publisher=Vintage Books | year=1994 | id=ISBN 0679761837}}</ref> Others maintain that love exists but is undefinable; being a quantity which is [[spirituality|spiritual]], [[metaphysical]], or [[philosophical]] in nature. Love is one of the most common themes in art.
  +
Friedrich Nietzsche charged that love as other-regard was merely an ideology constructed by the weak to mask their "resentment," by which he meant a repressed, self-deceiving, and self-poisoning rage about individual and collective powerlessness. Responses to Nietzsche find his own assumptions to be ideological and unsupported by gratuitous premises that self-interest and the "will to power" overshadow all other concerns. Further analysis and resources about this vital discussion are available in Ch. 5, The Fullness of Freedom: Confirming the Other; Roderick Hindery, Indoctrination and Self-deception or Free and Critical Thought?
